osce_questions.addressed_gap: Gap: Differentiating urticarial vasculitis from angioedema, particularly when swelling is present.
osce_questions.prompt: A 40-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of swelling involving her lips and tongue, along with itchy, raised welts on her arms and legs that last approximately 36 hours. She also reports mild abdominal cramping. Which of the following features would be MOST suggestive of urticarial vasculitis rather than angioedema?

options.A: Presence of lip and tongue swelling.
options.B: Itchy, raised welts on the skin.

osce_questions.explanation: While angioedema can present with lip and tongue swelling (A), itchy welts (B), and even abdominal symptoms (D), the presence of residual bruising after the welts resolve is a key differentiating feature of urticarial vasculitis (C).

concept_modal.specific: Bruising is a crucial clinical sign of vascular inflammation and damage, distinguishing urticarial vasculitis from other urticarial conditions and angioedema.
concept_modal.general: Careful observation of skin lesion morphology and evolution is essential for accurate dermatologic diagnosis.
concept_modal.lateral: This principle applies to differentiating other vasculitides based on cutaneous findings, such as palpable purpura in Henoch-Sch√∂nlein purpura.
